_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Operator check for ammonia leaks every four hours
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Anhydrous Ammonia

This process is a batch style process for a specific agricultural product.  The last production of this product ended in early 2007 with the ammonia tank emptied and decontaminated in 2008.  The product is scheduled to be produced in the future, therefore, the material will be maintained on the RMP plan.  Prior to production of the product, all operating procedures and skill set training in preparation for production will be reviewed, updated, and completed through the Management of Change Process similar to a new product introduction.  

This system is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of ammonia held in the storage tank. The unloading of ammonia tank trucks is also governed by Plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.
Ammonia pump (10-110-045B)

The storage tank is housed in a concrete diked area. All nozzles on the tank are fitted with excess flow valves except for nozzles with pressure relief valves. A local level indicator is available on the tank with a transmitter conveying  the level measurement into the control room. This instrument is used to monitor and control the tank level.

The pressure relief valves are tested annually. The entire system undergoes annual maintenance which includes: external inspection, checks for any leaks, bolt tightness on the manway. 

Ammonia is transferred to an ammonia / water mixer to prepare a solution that is pumped to a surge tank . The solution is then pumped to the chemical processing equipment and used to manufacture an agricultural product.

All changes to this system fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. Process Hazard Analyses (PHAs) are conducted for all changes.

_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Daily Tank & Equipment inspection & leak check
_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Computer based simulation of control systems
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Bromine, phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride are unloaded from top unloading bulk trailers into their respective storage tanks. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leak spots by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by utilizing the redundant equipment such as rupture disk followed by a relief valve.  All fumes from the unloading process,  storage tanks and process are neutralized in a scrubber.  The scrubber has multiple layers of redundancy, including emergency power, to ensure continuous operation.The tank farm area and process building are inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems.
Reactor (130-051)
Pump (110-020)
Reactor (120-001)
Reactor (150-001)
Pump (110-029)

The secondary containment areas for each storage tank are designed to hold or contain 110% of the storage tank volumes. Unique bulk containers and unloading stations are utilized to ensure that only the correct raw material can be unloaded into a given storage tank. Unloading procedures lock out and disable all non-participating unloading equipment.

The unloading system, storage tank and processing equipment are equipped with the instruments for monitoring process variables. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank over filling and over pressurization. The unloading process and storage tanks are monitored continuously by control and interlock systems. In addition, the process is also monitored continuously by trained operating personnel.

This process is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of materials held in the storage tank. The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by Plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.

All changes fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. PHAs are conducted for all changes.

_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Cylinders being used in the process are handled inside a building (the vaporizer building).
_prev_prog_3.MD_OtherType: Cl2 analyzer interlocked to building exhaust fan.
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Chlorine is transported to the plant site in one ton cylinders. These cylinders are transported on a flat-bed truck trailer equipped with a boom for off loading. One ton cylinders are widely available and are used in variety of industries. The chlorine supplier owns and maintains the cylinders.

The cylinders are off loaded with the boom and placed into cradles designed to transport and store the cylinders. The cradles are equipped with rollers for correctly orienting the cylinder valves and are also equipped with the means to securely lock the cylinder in place on the cradle. A forklift truck is used to transport the cylinder and  cradle to the cylinder storage shed. The shed is designed to protect the cylinders from the weather.

The forklift truck is also used to move the cylinders to the vaporizer building when chlorine is needed in the manufacturing process. One cylinder will be connected to the vaporization process equipment at a time. A maximum of eight cylinders will be allowed in the dispensing or vaporizer building at any time.

Unique pipe fittings are utilized to ensure that only chlorine is transferred to the process. The piping system is designed to minimize potential leak spots.

The chlorine vaporizer or dispensing building is inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems. It is also monitored continuously for chlorine leaks. If a leak is detected, the system will alarm, shutdown the transfer equipment, and automatically start ventilating  equipment. Trained operating staff will respond accordingly.

The chlorine transfer system and processing equipment are equipped with instruments for monitoring the process. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank overfilling and over pressurization. The process is monitored  continuously by control and interlock systems as well as trained operating personnel. A relatively low chlorine inventory in maintained in the process vessels. It reacts immediately.

This process operating procedures and administrative controls are designed to limit the chlorine inventory in the storage shed and dispensing buildings.  The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.

All changes fall under the Plant's process safety management of change procedure. PHAs are conducted for all changes.

Acrylonitrile shipments are unloaded from top unloading bulk trailers into its storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leak spots by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by utilizing the redundant equipment such as rupture disk followed by a relief valve.

All fumes from the unloading process, storage tank and process are neutralized in a scrubber.  The scrubber has multiple layers of redundancy, including emergency power, to ensure continuous operation.  The tank farm area and process building are inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems.

The secondary containment area for the storage tank is designed to hold or contain 110% of the storage tank volume.  Unique bulk container fittings (connectors)  are used to ensure that only the correct raw material can be unloaded into a given storage tank. Unloading procedures are used to lock out and disable all non-participating unloading equipment.

The unloading system, storage tank and processing equipment are equipped with the instruments for monitoring process variables. The system is designed to prevent events such as tank over filling and over pressurization. The unloading process and storage tank is monitored continuously by control and interlock systems. In addition, the process is also monitored continuously by highly trained operating personnel.

This process is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit  the amount of materials held in the storage tank. The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.

All changes fall under the plant's process safety management of change procedure. PHAs are conducted for all changes.

_prev_prog_3.TR_OtherType: Computer-based simulations of control systems and the on-line management of change program
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Anhydrous trimethylamine is unloaded from a high pressure, bulk trailer into a storage tank. Unique pipe fittings are used to ensure that only the correct raw material can be unloaded into the storage tank. The piping system design minimizes potential leak spots by utilizing the latest equipment such as "mag drive" pumps (no seals), excess flow valve on the bottom of the storage tank (stops flow if excessive, such as a leak), rupture disk followed by a relief valve, and low emission packing valves. The secondary containment area for the storage tank is designed to hold or contain 110% of the storage tank volume. All fumes from the tank farm and process vessels are burned in a thermal oxidizer.

Reactor 140-001

Reactor 220-001

Pump   220-004



The unloading system, storage tank and processing equipment are equipped with instruments for monitoring process variables. The system is designed to prevent incidents such as tank over filling and over pressurization. The unloading process and storage tank are monitored continuously by control and interlock systems. In addition, the process is also monitored continuously by trained operating personnel.



The tank farm area is inspected regularly for leaks and other potential problems. The process building is continuously monitored for trimethylamine as well as other chemicals. Upon detection of a trimethyamine leak in the process building the system will alarm and the trained operating staff will respond accordingly to isolate all equipment containing the amine.



The plant electrical systems meet all codes and guidelines for a facility handling flammable liquids. The unloading area, tank farm, and process building are equipped with appropriate fire-fighting systems.



The process is governed by well-documented operating procedures and administrative controls which limit the amount of trimethylamine held in the storage tank. The unloading of raw material delivery vehicles is also governed by Plant policies and operating procedures. Operators are trained and certified.



All changes fall under the Plant's process safety managment of change procedure. PHAs are conducted for all changes.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
At BASF Corporation's Hannibal Plant, we manufacture several agricultural products.  At this plant, we are very concerned with protecting our employees and our environment. We are also concerned with protecting our families that live in nearby communities.



We have designed our facilities to safely manage the chemicals used and produced by our production facilities. It is our policy to not only to comply with all applicable federal, state, and local rules and regulations but also to voluntarily go beyond these requirements to ensure our continued successful and safe operations.  We have developed and implemented the following to help achieve our goals:



* State of the art process equipment and process control design incorporating safety devices and systems needed to properly handle, store or use materials in our processes

* Well-defined and documented operating procedures and control systems

* An extensive safety, health and process safety management system

* Well-trained production employees coupled to a trained technical staff

* An extensive preventive maintenance and equipment inspection program

* Plant site access is restricted to authorized employees, management personnel, and authorized contractors



In addition to these preventative programs, it is the plant's policy to maintain an up-to-date emergency response plan and trained personnel and response equipment to be prepared to respond to potential emergencies involving fire, releases of hazardous material, medical emergencies, and confined space rescue. The plant works closely with area, community, emergency-response agencies providing them with information on plant operations and response programs in addition to conducting periodic training with members of the local emergency response agencies.



BASF's Hannibal facility has seven substances that exceed the RMP threshold quantities.  These compounds are acrylonitrile, anhydrous ammonia, bromine, chlorine, phosphorus oxychloride, phosphorus trichl

oride and trimethylamine.  Trimethylamine is classified as a flammable materials. The other materials are classified as toxic substances. All of these are used as raw materials to produce agricultural products.



Acrylonitile



Acrylonitrile, a liquid, is shipped to the plant by tank truck (about 40,000 pounds per tank truck). During unloading, the truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. Acrylonitrile is unloaded via top unloading system into its storage tank. A unique tank truck and unloading station are used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into the storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leaks by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by using the latest control devices.



The acrylonitrile storage tank is housed in a secondary containment area. It is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total plant inventory is about 66,000 pounds. This total includes the maximum allowable acrylonitrile in the storage tank, in pipes & hoses, and the amount in the chemical process.



Ammonia



Liquid, anhydrous ammonia is received by tank truck (approximately 26,000 pounds per truck) and is stored in a single steel tank at ambient temperature and under its own vapor pressure. This tank is located within a concrete secondary containment system.  The tank is equipped with overpressure protection and is rated to withstand full vacuum. The total ammonia inventory is 55,000 pounds. This includes the amount in the storage tank and associated piping that handle anhydrous ammonia. 



The anhydrous ammonia handling system consists of an unloading station with secondary containment system, a storage tank, two pumps and piping.  As for all operations at this facility, this system is governed by well-established operating proc

edures.



Bromine



Bromine, a liquid, is shipped to the plant by tank truck (about 40,000 pounds per truck). During unloading, the truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. Bromine is unloaded via top unloading system into its storage tank. A unique tank truck and unloading station are used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into the storage tank. The storage and handling system design minimizes potential leaks by eliminating all tank bottom nozzles and by using the latest control devices.



The bromine storage tank is housed in a diked area. It is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total plant inventory is about 100,000 pounds. This total includes the maximum allowable bromine in the storage tank and the amount in the chemical process.



Chlorine



Chlorine is shipped to the plant in one ton cylinders. One ton cylinders are widely available and are used in a variety of industries. Upon receipt, the cylinders are placed into specially designed cradles and transported to a cylinder storage shed for weather protection. When needed, the cylinders are moved to a separate building which houses a chlorine dispensing system which vaporizes the chlorine and conveys it to the chemical manufacturing process where it is consumed. One cylinder is connected to the dispensing system at a time. A maximum of eight cylinders is allowed in the dispensing building including the one being used. The maximum number of cylinders allowed on the plant site is twenty. The total plant inventory is 50,000 pounds.



Phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride



Phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride is also transported to the plant via tank truck. Both are liquids and are stored and handled in the same manner as bromine. Each tank truckload is ab

out 40,000 pounds. During unloading, each truck is stationed in a containment area designed to hold 110% of the truck's contents. A unique tank truck and unloading station are also used to ensure that only the correct raw material is unloaded into its designated storage tank.



The storage tanks for phosphorus oxychloride and phosphorus trichloride are installed in a diked area. Each material is pumped to the chemical processing equipment to make the agricultural products. A scrubber destroys all fumes from the unloading operation, the storage tank and the chemical processing steps. The total plant inventory of phosphorus oxychlorid is about 100,000 pounds. The total plant inventory of phosphorus trichloride is about 74,000 pounds.



Trimethylamine



Trimethylamine (TMA) is shipped to the plant in bulk trailers. Each shipment is about 40,000 pounds. TMA is shipped under pressure in the bulk trailer. Unique pipefittings are used to ensure that only the correct material is unloaded into the TMA storage tank. TMA is transferred to the chemical process to make an intermediate for an agricultural product. The total plant inventory is 83,000 pounds.



The Hannibal plant has a well-established accident prevention program. The primary purpose of the program is to eliminate those events which have the potential to result in personal injury, property loss and environmental or community impact. The secondary purpose of the program is to ensure reliable and predictable operations. The objective of the program is to eliminate all unexpected events. The program consists of four fundamental elements: (1) written procedures; (2) training; (3) auditing; (4) process reviews or evaluation.



(1) The written procedures include personal health and safety, work practices, equipment operation, loss prevention, and related topics. The procedures are implemented using administrative, engineering and personal protective equipment controls. The procedures receive periodic review and are

revised as necessary.



(2) The training element includes job specific safety, emergency response and hazard awareness training. Training plans are specifically developed for various employee groups. The frequency of the training varies within a three-year cycle depending upon the employee group and the topic.



(3) The auditing activities include both internal and external audits.  Internal audits are completed using a wide range of plant resources.  Plant personnel conduct routine general inspections of plant facilities on a regular basis (e.g. daily/weekly/monthly).  Facility personnel conduct extended plant-wide audits at a minimum three-year frequency.   These audits include safety, housekeeping, transportation, ergonomics, emergency systems, industrial hygiene, process safety management and mechanical integrity inspections.  Corporate and Division staff, state and federal agencies, insurance companies, etc. conduct external audits.



(4) Process Hazard Analyses are completed for each manufacturing and related support facilities on a 5-year cycle in accordance with applicable OSHA Process Safety Management regulations. Selected management of change activities also requires a hazard analysis. The analyses evaluate the impact of unexpected events to both in-plant and off-plant receptors.



Five-year accident history: The plant maintains records of all chemical releases. Our records document that we have had no accidental releases of the RMP-listed substances meeting the RMP rule criteria for the past five years.



The plant also has a well-established emergency response plan. Its primary purpose is to guide plant personnel during emergency situations. The secondary purpose is to communicate to the surrounding communities and area response agencies how the facility intends to respond to potential emergency situations. The plan's objective is to provide a coordinated response to potential plant emergencies that could threaten employee health and safety, the lo

cal community, the environment or plant property.



The plant maintains experienced personnel who are fully trained to respond to potential emergencies arising from fires, hazardous material releases, and medical emergencies and confined space incidents. The various teams are equipped to respond to plant emergencies.  The plant recognizes the potential need to utilize community emergency response agencies during some emergency situations. Therefore, plant emergency response teams work closely with members of the Palmyra, Hannibal, Quincy and Hannibal Rural Fire Departments sharing plant response information, conducting joint training exercises, providing emergency response support to communities for incidents not related to plant activities, and in many areas participating in local voluntary response agencies.



The Hannibal Plant has an effective safety program as indicated by its excellent safety performance record.  The plant has implemented effective programs to minimize the potential for off-site releases. At this time, there are no specific changes planned for the safety program related to the RMP activities. The Plant's Central EHS Committee meets on a regular basis to evaluate performance and to modify and improve the Safety and Environmental program as needed.
